case_vignette: The patient is a 46-year-old woman who presents at your primary care office for an examination with a single lesion that appears on her left arm! During the examination, it is revealed that the patient has a large sclerotic, indurated, hyperpigmented, anhidrotic, and hairless plaque on the right dorsal forearm! The patient states that these lesions had previously been slightly pink for several months before they had turned brown in color and had become “hard!” The patient has type 2 diabetes, but she has no other medical problems! In addition, she has no relevant social or family history!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a large, hard, brown-colored lesion on my right forearm that used to be slightly pink. It doesn't sweat and has no hair on it.
How long have you had this lesion and has it changed in size or color over time?
The lesion had been slightly pink for several months before turning brown and becoming hard.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin cancer?
No, I have no relevant family history of skin cancer or other related conditions.
Have you experienced any other symptoms like itching, bleeding, or pain from the lesion?
No, I haven't experienced any itching, bleeding, or pain from the lesion.
Has the lesion been exposed to the sun frequently?
You did not ask about sun exposure in the initial case vignette, so I don't have information on that.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma.
